LeftText: 1	Pierre Charles L'Enfant ,
2	Pierre Charles L'Enfant
3	( French :
4	[ pjɛʁ ʃɑʁl lɑ̃fɑ̃ ] ;
6	self - identified as Peter Charles L'Enfant
7	while living in the United States ,
8	was a French - born American military engineer
9	who designed the basic plan for Washington , D.C.
10	( capital city of the U.S. )
11	known today as the L'Enfant Plan
1	Pierre Charles L'Enfant ,
2	Pierre Charles L'Enfant
3	( French :
4	[ pjɛʁ ʃɑʁl lɑ̃fɑ̃ ] ;
RightText: 6	self - identified as Peter Charles L'Enfant
7	while living in the United States ,
8	was a French - born American military engineer
9	who designed the basic plan for Washington , D.C.
10	( capital city of the U.S. )
11	known today as the L'Enfant Plan

LeftText: 6	self - identified as Peter Charles L'Enfant
7	while living in the United States ,
8	was a French - born American military engineer
RightText: 9	who designed the basic plan for Washington , D.C.
10	( capital city of the U.S. )
11	known today as the L'Enfant Plan
13	Early life and education
14	L'Enfant was born in Paris , France on August 2 , 1754 , the third child and second son of Pierre L'Enfant
16	a painter with a good reputation in the service of King Louis XV of France ,
19	and Marie L'Enfant , the daughter of a minor official at court .
20	In 1758 , his brother Pierre Joseph died at the age of six ,
21	and Pierre Charles became the eldest son .
22	He studied art at the Royal Academy in the Louvre , as well as with his father at the Royal Academy of Painting and Sculpture .
23	He left school in France
24	to enlist in the American Revolutionary War on the side of the rebelling colonials .
25	Military service
26	L'Enfant was recruited by Pierre Augustin Caron de Beaumarchais
27	to serve in the American Revolutionary War in the United States .
28	He arrived in 1777 at the age of 23 ,
29	and served as a military engineer in the Continental Army with Major General Lafayette .
30	He was commissioned as a captain in the Corps of Engineers on April 3 , 1779
31	to rank from February 18 , 1778 .
32	Despite his aristocratic origins ,
33	L'Enfant closely identified with the United States ,
34	changing his first name from Pierre to Peter
35	when he first came to the rebelling colonies in 1777 .
36	L'Enfant served on General George Washington 's staff at Valley Forge .
37	While there ,
38	the Marquis de Lafayette commissioned L'Enfant to paint a portrait of Washington .
39	He was wounded at the Siege of Savannah on October 9 , 1779 .
40	He recovered
41	and became a prisoner of war at surrender of Charleston , South Carolina on May 12 , 1780 .
42	He was exchanged in November 1780
43	and served on General George Washington 's staff for the remainder of the American Revolution .
44	L'Enfant was promoted by brevet to Major in the Corps of Engineers on May 2 , 1783 , in recognition of his service to the cause of American liberty .
45	He was discharged
46	when the Continental Army was disbanded in December 1783 .
47	After the war ,
48	L'Enfant designed the badge of the Society of the Cincinnati , an organization of former officers of the Continental Army ,
49	shaped as an eagle ,
50	at the request of Washington .
51	He was sent to France
52	to have insignias made for members of the Society , a group of veterans of the war .
53	Career
54	Post–Revolutionary War
55	Following the American Revolutionary War ,
56	L'Enfant established a successful and highly profitable civil engineering firm in New York City .
57	He achieved some fame as an architect
58	by redesigning the City Hall in New York for the First Congress of the United States
59	( See :
60	Federal Hall ) .
61	He also designed furniture and houses for the wealthy as well as coins and medals ,
62	including the insignia of the Society of the Cincinnati .
63	He was also a friend of Alexander Hamilton ,
64	and some of their correspondances from 1790 to 1801 now reside in the National Archives .
65	While L'Enfant was in New York City ,
66	he was initiated into Freemasonry .
67	His initiation took place on April 17 , 1789 , at Holland Lodge No. 8 , F&AM ,
68	which the Grand Lodge of New York F&AM had chartered in 1787 .
69	L'Enfant took only the first of three degrees
70	offered by the Lodge
71	and did not progress further in Freemasonry .

53	Career
54	Post–Revolutionary War
55	Following the American Revolutionary War ,
56	L'Enfant established a successful and highly profitable civil engineering firm in New York City .
57	He achieved some fame as an architect
58	by redesigning the City Hall in New York for the First Congress of the United States
59	( See :
60	Federal Hall ) .
61	He also designed furniture and houses for the wealthy as well as coins and medals ,
62	including the insignia of the Society of the Cincinnati .
63	He was also a friend of Alexander Hamilton ,
64	and some of their correspondances from 1790 to 1801 now reside in the National Archives .
65	While L'Enfant was in New York City ,
66	he was initiated into Freemasonry .
67	His initiation took place on April 17 , 1789 , at Holland Lodge No. 8 , F&AM ,
68	which the Grand Lodge of New York F&AM had chartered in 1787 .
69	L'Enfant took only the first of three degrees
70	offered by the Lodge
71	and did not progress further in Freemasonry .
